newsitem.title: USA: Lower benefit costs best news "behind us"--SF Fed.
newsitem.headline: Lower benefit costs best news "behind us"--SF Fed.

text.p: Lower benefit costs have had a dampening effect on U.S. inflation, but the best news on that front is probably over, said the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, Robert Parry.

"The best news is perhaps behind us when it comes to those kinds of cost pressures. I think most analysts believe the biggest savings probably are behind us," Parry told reporters after a speech to the American Bar Association here.
Parry said earlier that companies enjoyed a deceleration of benefits costs as they shifted to managed medical care plans, which, in turn, helped keep inflation low.
Parry also said he was pleasantly surprised with the performance of the U.S. economy so far in 1997.
"I must admit things have turned out to be much more favorable than I thought they would be a year ago," the San Francisco Fed president said.
Parry said that by mid-1996 he thought that tighteness in labor and capital markets would cause inflationary pressures to begin to surface.
"But things have turned out very different. We've had growth that is stronger than I expected, an unemployment rate lower than I expected and inflation better than I expected," he added.
Earlier on Monday, Parry said he sees the U.S. economy growing between 2.0 and 2.5 percent over the next year or longer.
